description: Proposed change of use from Use Class E(a) (formerly A1) Retail Supermarket to E(b) (formally A3) Restaurant and installation of extractor system to rear
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the plant hereby permitted shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation.  The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade.  Measurements and assessment shall be made according to British Standard 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The ground floor E(b) use hereby permitted shall operate only between the hours of 08:00 to 23:00 Monday to Sunday, with all staff to leave the premises by 23:30 hours.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The application seeks approval of the details required by Condition 5 (detailed drawings)  of planning permission 24/01150/HOU.Condition 5 states 'Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, detailed drawings at a scale of minimum 1:10  of the following features shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority:- detailed drawings and specification (including finishes) of all new windows, doors and railingsThe development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved drawings.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.The submission comprises of the following - Application Form - Proposed Elevations  Drwg no 253/GA/08  at scale 1:100- Grabex Windows Reyndaers Aluminium Slimline 68 Window Brochure- Quotes and details from supplier  Officers note the submitted application form specifies that  all of the windows will be aluminium  as per the details  and the  proposed front and side elevation windows will be white and the rear grey in colour.Officers have reviewed the submitted proposed elevation drawing (Drwg no 253/GA/08) with the approved drawing ( Drawing No 253/PL/20) to which Condition 5. Officers note there are several design changes between the approved drawing and the current submitted drawing which include the  following :- additional rooflights,  - reduced/ enlarged  window openings, - removal of  existing windows to be blocked, - inclusion of additional extension previously not shown- extended quion to suit new roof level and change of roof angle  on rear elevationThese identified changes  on the submitted drawings  do not have planning approval  and such changes to a scheme cannot be made via a discharge of condition application. The applicant would need to first formally vary the original permission if they wish to amend what was approved. To formally amend the scheme the applicant would need to either submit a S96a non material amendment or Section 73 minor material amendment application. Any changes would need to be formally approved prior to the submission of a discharge of condition application.Officers conclude the details submitted to discharge Condition 5 ( detailed drawings) of planning permission 24/01150/HOU are unacceptable.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations7 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. 2no letters of objection received and states : Loss of light/ sunlightPrivacyExcessive height or bulk of buildingsA number of these material considerations will be included within the assessment. Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for   the erection of part single/ part two storey side and rear extension. Application SiteThe  site comprises a semi detached dwellingPlanning History24/02602/CPU - Erection of hip to gable and rear roof dormer extension and installation of 2nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion . Granted 16.12.24Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer comment : The proposal seeks approval for the erection of part single/ part two storey side and rear extension. The existing dwelling is positioned on the corner plot at the junction of Fullers Avenue and Agar Close. Within the plot the dwelling is not positioned  in parallel alignment  with neighbouring no 48 Fullers Avenue thereby presenting an angular separation gap between the properties.  In addition, Officers note the dwelling previously presented a  single storey  side 'enclosure' which extended to the shared boundary with neighbouring no 48 Fullers Avenue.At ground floor level, the proposed  depth of the rear extension would be compliant with the recommendations as set out in Policy Guidance 33 in the Residential Design SPD. Compliant with Policy Guidance 36, the proposed side extension would be set back from the front elevation of the existing dwelling by 1m and continue to extend towards the rear of the dwelling to conjoin with the proposed rear extension. Whilst the proposed side extension would exceed more than half the width of the original dwelling and not be set in by 1m from the shared boundary with neighbouring no 48 Fullers Avenue, in the knowledge there had previously been a ground floor  side 'enclosure'  the principle of the proposal would be considered acceptable.At the proposed first floor level,the proposed side and rear extension would be positioned within the built proposed ground floor side and rear extension  and set back from the boundary by a 1m  maintaining the existing gap between the properties thereby being compliant with the recommendations as set out in Policy Guidance  36. No new fenestration is proposed on the proposed side (west) elevation, however single windows would be introduced  on the proposed front and rear  elevations.A hybrid roof arrangement is proposed creating additional roofspace  consisting of a dual pitch roof arrangement  which would be set down  and off set from the main roof ridge of the main dwelling together with a hip gable roof arrangement  for the proposed  first floor rear extension.Overall, in the context of the existing built form on site and the siting of the part single/ part two storey side and rear extension, it is  considered that the proposal would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwellinghouse and that it would be acceptable from a character and design perspective.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The principal property to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property at no 48  Fullers Avenue. Concern has  been raised with regards to the level of sunlight getting to the neighbouring property during the day.Officers  have considered the proposal in the context of BRE guidelines (2022) and note that the existing two storey dwelling together with no 48  Fullers Avenue and existing garage and outbuilding already casts shadow  within the neighbouring garden of  no48 Fullers Avenue. It is considered that the addition of a  part single/ part two storey side extension single storey rear extension  would not significantly contribute to the existing situation  In addition,  in the context of the guidelines  Officers considered that the  existing garden at no 48 Fullers Avenue  would be adequately sunlit throughout the year, and at least half of a garden or amenity area should receive at least two hours of sunlight on 21 MarchOfficer Comment:  Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Escape Plans .  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal
The submitted existing and proposed floor plan and elevations do not have a scale bar, please revise the existing and proposed floor plan and elevations with correct scale bar.
